text: [Music]
j.cole hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for
your review of the new J Cole album born
sinner J Cole is rapper producer and one
of the more worthwhile artists that
jay-z is put on in a while and jay-z
endorsing this guy having him on the
blueprint and signing him through rock
Nation did really give him a huge heap
of attention and I don't think anyone
could argue that J Cole didn't take
advantage of the opportunity his best
that he could with some really buzz
building EPS and mixtapes and then with
Cole world in 2011 the sideline story on
this album Cole showed his versatility
because he did have some club tracks on
there he did have some singles some hits
as well as more personal and socially
conscious moments as well well well and
Cole's production talents on this album
led to a lot of beats that were
cinematic beautiful sort of moving at
points my biggest issue on this LP
though was kind of the consistency
between the songs and just the lyricism
when he brags and sort of centers on
himself I don't really see what makes
him different than any other guy out
there it's not like he's the only
conscious rapper out there is making a
lot of waves too you have artists like
Big KRIT and Kendrick Lamar who are
doing conscious hip-hop right now that
is bolder grittier and incredibly
emotional now born sinner in a way is
sort of an improvement over the sideline
story I think because it definitely
doesn't feel like an album where Cole
had a ton of pressure to come out with a
radio single or at least produce a radio
single that sounded like everybody
else's radio single however the album
still comes through pretty disjointed
despite the title despite the really
dramatic cover art and the fact that
Cole comes right out front and center at
the start of the album and says it's way
darker this time J Cole lyrically and
and emotionally doesn't sound any more
conflicted tortured or even more
religious than he did on his last full
length the instrumental talent on this
LP is still there for sure the opening
track of Illuminati has this heavily
heavily rhythmic beat lots of detail on
these drums and the
soaring whimsical strings at a really
dramatic vadik Matt it feels like he
nabbed it from the r.kelly track I wish
the B is great I've tuned in I want to
hear what Cole is going to say but it
turns out that all he's done is is
really just heir to rerun he's rapping
again about how he chased down jay-z to
listen to his stuff
then there's haters and internet rappers
and then as if it couldn't get any worse
an incredibly stupid use of the word
[ __ ] in the song Cole spends the next
few lines justifying his use of the word
saying over you offended you shouldn't
be so sensitive oh yeah you're
homophobic for getting offended at that
since when is the person who gets
offended at the use of that word the
homophobe typically the user is the
homophobe and what's funny is a little
further down the line he calls someone a
[ __ ] but he doesn't feel the need to
justify that I guess retards okay but
[ __ ] bad the only moment in the track
lyrically that I think was impressive
was the spot where he talked about
Barack Obama apologizing to the Japanese
and then saying where is the president's
apology to the impoverished people who
are suffering in urban America today and
you know of course I mean that's an
interesting statement but it's not
exactly like Cole is the first person to
make that statement and and it's not
like after some of the lines on this
track track track that you would want
him to represent this statement the
track land of snakes has a sample from a
great Outkast song from their album ik
women I and yeah it sort of serves as as
I want to say a very nostalgic backdrop
for Cole as he reminisces about this
love story in his past and it basically
goes like he slept with a girl he hung
her out to dry then she confronted him
on it and and I think he might have felt
bad maybe a baby dose that it's really
hard to tell because there's not really
a moment in this track where Cole feels
really emotional or remorseful and he's
rapping about painting a picture of his
pain and I'm not really seeing the pain
at all on on this track it's actually
pretty mundane story how he describes it
I just don't see what's so special about
this story or his delivery on it he
doesn't even seem the least bit upset
that this girl slipped through his
fingers
or that he might have treated her
wrongly and what's even more ridiculous
is on the song power trip Cole finds
himself obsessing over a girl or a girl
and with the really kind of flat
distorted very Niall beat on this song
the best things about this track are the
Hubert laws sample with the jazz flute
and Miguel who actually did a great job
of singing on this track and if he
wasn't on it it would have no single
potential whatsoever it boggles my mind
that this was the lead single off of
this LP it's not just Cole's lack of
oomph that really ruins these songs or
makes them forgettable though sometimes
it's it's sort of what he says - that's
kind of outlandish like the song trouble
where honestly the lyrics to the hook on
this track especially at the end of the
chorus where he says gunshots in the air
but I am scared for my life
this entire chorus sounds like a rap
parody it's kind of ridiculous to think
that this same guy wrote that girl guy
verse exchange on the song lost ones
from Cole's last album I mean that song
was incredibly emotional in my opinion a
little outlandish with its concept with
him rapping from the standpoint of a
girl in another verse but still you
gotta admire the guy's balls for trying
something like that out and now
something like a similar situation on
this album ends up being sort of a
stupid punchline like mama did you [ __ ]
J Cole and Cole continues to dish out
more stories of heartbreak over women
the dude is turning into Drake but it's
not even good introspective deep dark
sad Drake today this is like mixtape
Drake except the hooks singing and beats
do not pop and the only thing keeping
these songs sort of relevant to the
theme of this album are Cole's very
small lyrical detours into career money
and and morals things on this LP get a
little bit more personal and ideological
like on the 9th track here where Cole is
dealing a lot with people who are rich
people who are poor and the song
forbidden fruit which actually has
Kendrick Lamar sadly he doesn't really
go in on a great verse on this song
but even as Cole tries to make some
wider statements on these tracks he
continues to say things that make it
difficult to take him seriously like how
he's dropping his album the same
the Kanye is dropping his there are just
a lot of spots on this LP where Cole
seems too obsessed with temporary dramas
to to make a long lasting statement it's
like it's not going to get any better
than this and he's not seeing that his
efforts are just merely building up to
be footprints that are gonna get washed
away in the waves if the track crooked
smile with TLC on this LP isn't begging
to be washed away I don't know what is
honestly the only riveting tracks on
this LP the only songs that I really
really liked were the songs that came
toward the end namely let nas down it's
got a really silky sweet sexy jazz
sample throughout the track it's it's a
really epic instrumental and the song is
essentially about dealing with the
disappointment of hearing that one of
his hip-hop heroes disliked one of his
big singles and Cole does not come off
as a lyrical God on this song but he
does feel really emotional the song
itself feels way more inspired than most
of the tracks on this LP I love how Cole
sort of makes a God of nos he obsesses
over him he goes into his past but still
is aware enough to call nas out on his
shortcomings with dropping singles not
only you owe me but I think he could
have referenced summer on smash and yeah
maybe Cole is not in the position to
make these kinds of statements given the
nas has a few classics under his belt
but you could argue that if Cole
continued to make moves this ballsy he
might have a classic or two under his
belt at this point the closing track on
this LP is beautiful it really delves
into a lot of those moral and religious
themes that you would assume would come
with an album of this title but honestly
it's just too little too late I'm
feeling a decent two strong five five
five
if you've given it a listen what did you
think of it did you love it hate it why
what should i review next and that's it
